div.head: 11.8.1885 Dienstag
div.p: Again worked in the same place in the morning. In the afternoon read the papers and walked up to Staffelhöhe with Mamma and Baby. As it began to lighten and thunder we walked back very soon though and I wrote and read in Mamma’s room. Mamma read the last two chapters of Mad. de Mineleko to me, which she has shortly written. She is now working at Wilma de Lashas. which she began in April while Lemerre was reading Roland. Danced in the evening. This morning at five the Steamwashapparatus began to go and woke everyone up. It sounds like a battery of cannons. Du reste we are not spared noise here. There was an individual on my landing who began grating his violin and producing the most heartwrending sound every morning before six. Thank goodness he is gone now. There is also a female who begins to thump the piano at five in the morning and pierces the temples and nerves of the house inmates with the most terrifying shrieks. In fact if one was to describe all the inhabitants of the Kaltbad one could get together a good lot of cures. There is that Roumanian with a craze on Sarah Bernhardt, with frizzly hair, a cadaverous looking face and wild eyes. À propos of her, the other day when her bathing woman did not dry her properly she went to her dressing table, pulled out a dagger and. told the terrified woman that if she did not dry her on the spot she would kill her. There is old baron Oppenheim whose whig nearly flew away the other day and who always walks as if he had got the stomack ache, there is the „femme au panache“ with the white feathers towering high above her, there is Mother Goose Ricardo with her rouge and cosmetics and yellow dresses and red and pink hats and juvenile look and 90 years, then old Ibrahim who is in love with prince George and last but not least old Mariassi with her brown veil and dust cloak, who always sits with her back to the mountains: The charlatan is represented by D r Hermann. 4500 cases and 1663 deaths of the cholera in Spain yesterday. German demonstration before Zanzibar and General Grant’s funeral are the great topics now.
